title: Pliny Ep 9 21 - we learn in lines 8-10

content.description:
Directions: Read the following selection carefully for comprehension. The selection is followed by a number of related questions and incomplete statements. Select the best answer or completion.

Pliny writes a letter to a friend on behalf of a freedman.

Libertus tuus, cui suscensere1 te dixeras, venit ad me

advolutusque2 pedibus meis tamquam3 tuis haesit. Flevit

multum, multum rogavit, multum etiam tacuit, in summā4

fecit mihi fidem paenitentiae verae: credo emendatum5

(5) quia deliquisse se sentit. Irasceris6 scio, et irasceris merito,

id quoque scio; sed tunc praecipua7 mansuetudinis8 laus,

cum irae causa iustissima est. Amasti hominem et, spero,

amabis: interim sufficit ut exorari9 te sinas. Licebit

rursus irasci, si meruerit, quod exoratus excusatius

(10) facies. Remitte10 aliquid adulescentiae ipsius, remitte

lacrimis, remitte indulgentiae tuae. Vereor ne videar non

rogare sed cogere, si precibus eius meas iunxero; iungam

tamen tanto plenius et effusius, quanto ipsum acrius

severiusque corripui,11 destricte12 minatus numquam me postea rogaturum.

1 suscenseo, ere: be angry

2 advolutus, -a, -um: having thrown oneself at

3 tamquam: just as if

4 in summā (from summa, -ae, f.: summary): to sum it up; in conclusion

5 emendo, -are, -avi, -atum: reform

6 irascor, -i: get angry

7 praecipuus, -a, -um: special

8 mansuetudo, -inis, f.: mildness, mercy

9 exoro, -are, -avi, -atum: win over

10 remitto, -ere: concede

11 corripio, -ere: reproach, blame

12 destricte: severely
content.question: With the words Licebit . . . facies (lines 8-10), Pliny makes the point that

choices.label: his friend may be justifiably angry with the freedman if he misbehaves again
excessive anger may be excused on occasion
if the freedman gets angry again, he will deserve to be reprimanded
the freedman will be permitted to make excuses if asked

content.answer: his friend may be justifiably angry with the freedman if he misbehaves again
